title: Alice Springs
text:
Alice Springs () is the third-largest town in the <a href="Northern%20Territory">Northern Territory</a> of <a href="Australia">Australia</a>. Known as Stuart until 31 August 1933, the name Alice Springs was given by surveyor <a href="William%20Mills%20%28surveyor%29">William Whitfield Mills</a> after Alice, Lady Todd ("née" Alice Gillam Bell), wife of the telegraph pioneer Sir <a href="Charles%20Todd%20%28pioneer%29">Charles Todd</a>. Known colloquially as The Alice or simply Alice, the town is situated roughly in Australia's geographic centre. It is nearly <a href="equidistant">equidistant</a> from <a href="Adelaide">Adelaide</a> and <a href="Darwin%2C%20Northern%20Territory">Darwin</a>.
The area is known as to its <a href="Indigenous%20Australians">original inhabitants</a>, the <a href="Arrernte%20people">Arrernte</a>, who have lived in the Central Australian desert in and around what is now Alice Springs for tens of thousands of years.
Alice Springs had an urban population of 26,534 in June 2018, having declined an average of 1.16% per year the preceding five years. The town's population accounts for approximately 10 per cent of the population of the Northern Territory.
The town straddles the usually dry <a href="Todd%20River">Todd River</a> on the northern side of the <a href="MacDonnell%20Ranges">MacDonnell Ranges</a>. The surrounding region is known as Central Australia, or the <a href="Red%20Centre">Red Centre</a>, an arid environment consisting of several deserts. Temperatures in Alice Springs can vary, with an average maximum in summer of and an average minimum in winter of .
History.
Traditional owners.
The <a href="Arrernte%20people">Arrernte</a> people are the traditional owners of the Alice Springs area and surrounding <a href="MacDonnell%20Ranges">MacDonnell Ranges</a>. They have lived in the area for at least 30,000 years. The traditional name for the township area is "Mparntwe".
Their name has been spelt in various forms, including Aranda, Arrarnta, and Arunta. There are five dialects of the Arrernte language: South-eastern, Central, Northern, Eastern and North-eastern.
Arrernte country is rich with mountain ranges, waterholes and gorges, which create a variety of natural habitats. According to Arrernte traditional histories, the landscape was shaped by the Yeperenye, Ntyarlke, Utnerrengatye caterpillars and Akngwelye or wild dogs.
The numerous sites of traditional importance in and around Alice Springs include Anthwerrke (Emily Gap), Akeyulerre (Billy Goat Hill), Ntaripe (<a href="Heavitree%20Gap">Heavitree Gap</a>), Atnelkentyarliweke (<a href="Anzac%20Hill">Anzac Hill</a>) and Alhekulyele (Mt Gillen).
European settlement.
In 1861–62, <a href="John%20McDouall%20Stuart">John McDouall Stuart</a> led an expedition through Central Australia, to the west of what later became Alice Springs, thereby establishing a route from the south of the continent to the north.
A settlement named after Stuart was necessitated ten years later with the construction of a repeater station on the <a href="Australian%20Overland%20Telegraph%20Line">Australian Overland Telegraph Line</a> (OTL), which linked <a href="Adelaide">Adelaide</a> to <a href="Darwin%2C%20Northern%20Territory">Darwin</a> and <a href="Great%20Britain">Great Britain</a>. The OTL was completed in 1872. It traced Stuart's route and opened up the interior for permanent settlement. The <a href="Alice%20Springs%20Telegraph%20Station">Alice Springs Telegraph Station</a> was sited near what was thought to be a permanent waterhole in the normally dry <a href="Todd%20River">Todd River</a>, named Alice Springs by W.W. Mills after the wife of the Superintendent of Telegraphs and Postmaster General of South Australia, Sir <a href="Charles%20Todd%20%28pioneer%29">Charles Todd</a>, who was the driving force for constructing the OTL. The nearby settlement of Stuart was renamed as Alice Springs on 31 August 1933. The Todd River and its tributary the Charles River, which meet near the telegraph station, were named after Sir Charles.
It was not until <a href="Alluvium">alluvial</a> gold was discovered at Arltunga, east of the present Alice Springs, in 1887 that any significant European settlement occurred. The town's first substantial building was the <a href="Stuart%20Town%20Gaol">Stuart Town Gaol</a> in Parson's Street; this was built in 1909, when the town had a European population of fewer than 20 people. Many of the gaol's first prisoners were first-contact aboriginal men incarcerated for killing cattle. The first aircraft, piloted by <a href="Francis%20Stewart%20Briggs">Francis Stewart Briggs</a> landed in 1921. Central Australia's first hospital, Adelaide House, was built in 1926 when the European population of the town was about 40. It was not until 1929, when the train line to Alice was built, that the town's European population began to grow. Aboriginal Centralians outnumbered European Centralians until the mid-1930s. From 1926 to 1931, Alice Springs was the seat of government for the now-defunct <a href="Central%20Australia%20%28territory%29">Territory of Central Australia</a>. Until 31 August 1933, the town was officially known as Stuart.
The original mode of British-Australian transportation in the outback were <a href="camel">camel</a> trains, operated by immigrants from <a href="Pashtun%20people">Pathan</a> tribes in the <a href="Military%20history%20of%20the%20North-West%20Frontier">North-West Frontier</a> of then-<a href="British%20India">British India</a> (present-day Pakistan), known locally as <a href="Afghan%20%28Australia%29">Afghan</a> cameleers based at Hergott Springs, or Marree as it is now known. Many cameleers moved to Alice Springs in 1929 when the railway finally reached the town. They lived on the block where the town council is now, transporting goods from the rail head to stations and settlements to the north. A gold rush in Tennant Creek in 1932 kept the wheels of the Alice Springs economy turning until the outbreak of <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>.
Alice Springs was connected to Darwin by rail on 4 February 2004, when <a href="The%20Ghan">the first passenger train</a> arrived in Darwin from Adelaide.
World War II.
<a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a> brought significant changes to Alice Springs. Prior to the war, Alice Springs was an extremely isolated settlement of fewer than 500 people. During the war, however, the town was an extremely active staging base, known as No. 9 Australian Staging Camp, and a depot base for the long four-day trip to Darwin. The railway hub in Alice Springs was taken over by military operations and the number of soldiers posted in Alice Springs grew rapidly, as did the number of personnel passing through on their way to and from Darwin. When Darwin was threatened by Japanese forces, the sea routes—the Northern Territory capital's primary means of transportation and resupply—were cut off. The evacuation of Darwin first brought a large number of civilians including elected officials and many of the territory government's records. Alice Springs became the war-time civilian capital of the Northern Territory. When Darwin was bombed by Japanese air forces, a large number of military personnel and their heavy equipment were rapidly moved south to Alice Springs.
The number of soldiers posted in Alice Springs peaked at around 8,000 and the number of personnel passing through totalled close to 200,000. Once the war ended, the military camps and the evacuees departed, and Alice Springs' population declined rapidly. After being visited by nearly 200,000 people, including the American General <a href="Douglas%20MacArthur">Douglas MacArthur</a>, Alice Springs gained considerable fame. The war years also left behind many structures. The historically-listed <a href="Totem%20Theatre">Totem Theatre</a>, created for the entertainment of this camp, still exists today. The <a href="Australian%20Army">Australian Army</a> set up the 109th Australian General Hospital at Alice Springs. <a href="Alice%20Springs%20Airport">Seven Mile Aerodrome</a> was constructed by the <a href="Royal%20Australian%20Air%20Force">Royal Australian Air Force</a>. War-related operations necessitated the first sealing of the road between Alice Springs and Larrimah, expansion and improvement of Alice Springs' water supply, and improving the rail head. The war-related operations left behind thousands of pieces of excess military equipment and vehicles, and a marked increase in Alice Springs' population.
During World War II, Alice Springs was the location of <a href="List%20of%20RAAF%20inland%20aircraft%20fuel%20depots">RAAF No. 24 Inland Aircraft Fuel Depot</a> (IAFD), completed on 20 May 1942 and closed in November 1944. Each usually consisting of four tanks, 31 fuel depots were built across Australia for the storage and supply of aircraft fuel for the <a href="RAAF">RAAF</a> and the <a href="US%20Army%20Air%20Forces">US Army Air Forces</a>, at a total cost of £900,000 ($1,800,000).
After World War II.
During the 1960s Alice Springs became an important defence location with the development of the US/Australian <a href="Pine%20Gap">Pine Gap</a> joint defence <a href="satellite">satellite</a> monitoring base, home to about 700 workers from both countries.
By far the major industry in recent times is tourism. Almost in the exact centre of the continent, Alice Springs is some from the nearest ocean and from the nearest major cities, Darwin and Adelaide. Alice Springs is at the midpoint of the <a href="The%20Ghan">Adelaide–Darwin Railway</a>.
Modern town.
The modern town of Alice Springs has both European and Aboriginal influences. The town's focal point, the <a href="Todd%20Mall">Todd Mall</a>, hosts a number of Aboriginal art galleries and community events. Alice Springs' desert lifestyle has inspired several unique events, such as the Camel Cup, the <a href="Henley-on-Todd%20Regatta">Henley-on-Todd Regatta</a>, Beanie Festival and the Tatts Finke Desert Race.
Built environment.
Alice Springs has many historic buildings, including the <a href="Overland%20Telegraph">Overland Telegraph Station</a>, the Old Courthouse and <a href="The%20Residency%2C%20Alice%20Springs">Residency</a> and the <a href="Hartley%20Street%20School">Hartley Street School</a>. <a href="Adelaide%20House%20%28Alice%20Springs%29">Adelaide House</a>, a beautiful stone building in the middle of the Mall, Central Australia's first hospital, was designed and built by the Rev. John Flynn, founder of the world's first flying doctor service, in 1926. It was also the site of the world's first successful portable wireless radio experiment conducted by Alf Traeger. Today it is a museum, one of several significant tourist attractions which form part of 'The Flynn Trail' a self-guided urban heritage trail.
Today, the town is an important tourist hub and service centre for the surrounding area. It is a well-appointed town for its size, with several large hotels, a world-class convention centre, and a good range of visitor attractions, restaurants, and other services.
Geography.
The region around Alice Springs is part of the <a href="Central%20Ranges%20xeric%20scrub">Central Ranges xeric scrub</a> area of dry scrubby grassland and includes the <a href="MacDonnell%20Ranges">MacDonnell Ranges</a> which run east and west of the town and contain a number of hiking trails and swimming holes such as <a href="Ormiston%20Gorge">Ormiston Gorge</a>, Ormiston Gorge Creek, Red Bank Gorge and <a href="Glen%20Helen%20Gorge">Glen Helen Gorge</a>. The <a href="Larapinta%20Trail">Larapinta Trail</a> follows the West MacDonnell Ranges and is considered among the world's great walking experiences.
The <a href="Simpson%20Desert">Simpson Desert</a>, southeast of Alice Springs is one of Australia's great wilderness areas containing giant, red sand dunes and rock formations such as <a href="Chambers%20Pillar">Chambers Pillar</a> and Rainbow Valley.
Climate.
Under the <a href="K%C3%B6ppen%20climate%20classification">Köppen climate classification</a>, Alice Springs has a subtropical <a href="hot%20desert%20climate">hot desert climate</a> ("BWh"), featuring extremely hot, dry summers and short, mild winters. Located just south of the <a href="Tropic%20of%20Capricorn">Tropic of Capricorn</a>, the town of Alice Springs straddles the usually dry <a href="Todd%20River">Todd River</a> on the northern side of the <a href="MacDonnell%20Ranges">MacDonnell Ranges</a>. Alice Springs is located in Central Australia, also called the Red Centre, an arid environment consisting of several different deserts. The annual average rainfall is which would make it a <a href="semi-arid%20climate">semi-arid climate</a> except that its high <a href="evapotranspiration">evapotranspiration</a>, or its aridity, makes it a <a href="desert%20climate">desert climate</a>.
Annual precipitation is erratic, varying year to year in Alice Springs. In 2001 fell and in 2002 only fell. The highest daily rainfall is , recorded on 31 March 1988.
Temperatures in Alice Springs vary widely, and rainfall can vary quite dramatically from year to year. In summer, the average maximum temperature is in the mid-30s, whereas in winter the average minimum temperature can be , with an average of 12.4 nights below freezing every year, providing <a href="frost">frost</a>. The elevation of the town is about , which contributes to the cool nights in winter. The highest temperature on record is first recorded on 24 December 1891, whilst the record low is , recorded on 17 July 1976. This is also the lowest temperature recorded in the Northern Territory.
Demographics.
According to the <a href="Census%20in%20Australia%232016">2016 census</a> of population, there were 23,726 people in the Alice Springs Urban Area.
Aboriginal population.
As Alice Springs is the regional hub of Central Australia, it attracts Aboriginal people from all over that region and well beyond. Many Aboriginal people visit regularly to use the town's services. Aboriginal residents usually live in the suburbs, on special purpose leases (or town camps), or further out at <a href="Amoonguna">Amoonguna</a> to the south and on the small family outstation communities on Aboriginal lands in surrounding areas.
The traditional owners of the Alice Springs area are the <a href="Central%20Arrernte">Central Arrernte</a> people. As it is the largest town in central Australia, there are also speakers of <a href="Warlpiri%20language">Warlpiri</a>, <a href="Warumungu%20language">Warumungu</a>, <a href="Kaytetye%20language">Kaytetye</a>, <a href="Alyawarre">Alyawarre</a>, <a href="Luritja">Luritja</a>, <a href="Pintupi">Pintupi</a>, <a href="Pitjantjatjara%20language">Pitjantjatjara</a>, <a href="Yankunytjatjara%20language">Yankunytjatjara</a>, <a href="Ngaanyatjarra">Ngaanyatjarra</a>, <a href="Pertame">Pertame</a>, <a href="Eastern%20Arrernte">Eastern</a>, and <a href="Western%20Arrernte">Western Arrernte</a> among others.
Foreign and itinerant populations.
American population.
<a href="Americans">Americans</a> have lived in Alice Springs continuously since the establishment of the United States Air Force Detachment 421, in 1954. Currently located on Schwarz Crescent, it is part of a joint American–Australian project called the Joint Geological and Geographical Research Station (JGGRS). The unit is locally known as "Det 421" or "The Det" and has sponsored as many as 25 American families to live as temporary residents of the Alice Springs district.
To mark the longstanding friendship with the community, on 1 July 1995, the Alice Springs Town Council granted Detachment 421 freedom of entry to Alice Springs. Since the early 1970s, the majority of the American population in Alice Springs has been associated with proximity to <a href="Pine%20Gap">Pine Gap</a>, a joint Australian-US satellite tracking station, located south-west of Alice Springs, that employs about 700 Americans and Australians.
Currently, 2,000 residents of the Alice Springs district hold American citizenship. Many of these, joined by some Australians, celebrate major American public holidays, including the <a href="Independence%20Day%20%28United%20States%29">4th of July</a> and <a href="Thanksgiving%20%28United%20States%29">Thanksgiving</a>. Americans in Alice Springs are also known to participate in a variety of associations and sporting teams, including baseball, basketball and soccer competitions.
Other cultures.
Several small immigrant communities of other foreign cultures have found a home in Alice Springs, including Vietnamese, Chinese, Thai, Sudanese and <a href="Indian%20people">Indian ethnic groups</a>. The most obvious impact of their presence in such a small and isolated town has been the opening of various restaurants serving their traditional cuisines.
Itinerant population.
Alice Springs has a large <a href="wikt%3Aitinerant">itinerant</a> population. This population is generally composed of foreign and Australian tourists, Aboriginal Australians visiting from nearby <a href="Central%20Australia">Central Australia</a>n communities, and Australian or international workers on short-term contracts (colloquially referred to as "blow-ins"). The major sources of work that recruit workers into town are the stations, mines, healthcare and law enforcement. Foreign tourists usually pass through on their way to <a href="Uluru-Kata%20Tjuta%20National%20Park">Uluru-Kata Tjuta National Park</a>, whilst Australian tourists usually come through as a part of an event such as the <a href="Masters%20Games">Masters Games</a> and the <a href="Finke%20Desert%20Race">Finke Desert Race</a>. These events can cause the population of the town to fluctuate by several thousand within a matter of days.
Government.
The <a href="Alice%20Springs%20Town%20Council">Alice Springs Town Council</a> governs the Alice Springs area, which takes in the town centre, its suburbs and some rural area. The Alice Springs Town Council has governed Alice Springs since 1971. The Alice Springs council consists of nine members: the mayor and eight <a href="aldermen">aldermen</a>. The town is not divided up into wards. The current mayor of Alice Springs is Damien Ryan. Council Meetings are held on the last Monday of each month. The <a href="Central%20Australia">Alice Springs Region</a> is governed by the newly created <a href="MacDonnell%20Region">MacDonnell Region</a> <a href="local%20government%20area">local government area</a>, for which Alice Springs serves as council seat.
Alice Springs and the surrounding region have four elected members to the <a href="Northern%20Territory%20Legislative%20Assembly">Northern Territory Legislative Assembly</a>. <a href="Electoral%20division%20of%20Araluen">Araluen</a> and <a href="Electoral%20division%20of%20Braitling">Braitling</a> are entirely within Alice Springs, while the mostly rural seats of <a href="Electoral%20division%20of%20Gwoja">Gwoja</a> (known as <a href="Electoral%20division%20of%20Stuart">Stuart</a> before 2020) and <a href="electoral%20division%20of%20Namatjira">Namatjira</a> spill into the town. Historically, Alice Springs has tilted conservative. It was a stronghold for the <a href="Country%20Liberal%20Party">Country Liberal Party</a> for many years; only the northeast (part of which is in Stuart) leans <a href="Australian%20Labor%20Party">Labor</a>. However, these trends were dramatically altered at the <a href="2016%20Northern%20Territory%20general%20election">2016 election</a>. Former Chief Minister and Alice Springs resident <a href="Adam%20Giles">Adam Giles</a> lost Braitling to Labor, Araluen was retained by CLP-turned-independent <a href="Robyn%20Lambley">Robyn Lambley</a>, and Namatjira and Stuart fell to Labor. As a result, the CLP was completely shut out of Alice Springs for the first time ever. The CLP regained Braitling and Namatjira in 2020, while Lambley retained Araluen for her new party, the <a href="Territory%20Alliance">Territory Alliance</a>.
In the <a href="Australian%20House%20of%20Representatives">Australian House of Representatives</a>, Alice Springs is part of the <a href="Division%20of%20Lingiari">Division of Lingiari</a>, which includes all of the Territory outside the Darwin/Palmerston area. Lingiari is currently held by Labor member and Alice Springs resident <a href="Warren%20Snowdon">Warren Snowdon</a>.
Economy.
Alice Springs began as a service town to the pastoral industry that first came to the region. The introduction of the rail line increased its economy. Today the town services a region of and a regional population of 38,749. The region includes a number of mining and pastoral communities, the Joint Defence Space Research Facility at <a href="Pine%20Gap">Pine Gap</a> and tourist attractions at <a href="Uluru-Kata%20Tjuta%20National%20Park">Uluru-Kata Tjuta National Park</a>, <a href="Watarrka%20National%20Park">Watarrka National Park</a> and the <a href="MacDonnell%20Ranges">MacDonnell Ranges</a>.
The largest employer in Alice Springs is the Northern Territory Government, with 8% of employed people working in government administration, 7% in school education, and 4% in the Alice Springs Hospital. The economy of Alice Springs is somewhat reliant on domestic and international tourism, with 4% of its workforce employed providing accommodation. 
As well as Territory Discoveries, all major tour companies have a base in Alice Springs, including AAT Kings & APT, as well as numerous local operators, including Emu Run Tours, Anganu Waai! tours, Alice Wanderer and Wayoutback Desert Safaris, the only locally based Advanced <a href="Ecotourism">Ecotourism</a> Accredited operator.
Alice Springs is home to numerous hotels, from the -star <a href="Lasseters%20Hotel%20Casino">Lasseters Hotel Casino</a>, to backpacker hostels. There are also caravan parks.
A dispatch centre for the <a href="Royal%20Flying%20Doctor%20Service%20of%20Australia">Royal Flying Doctor Service of Australia</a> operates here.
Education.
Education is overseen territory-wide by the Department of Education and Training (DET). It works to continually improve education outcomes for all students, with a focus on Indigenous students.
Preschool, primary and secondary.
Alice Springs is served by nineteen public and private schools that cater to local and overseas students. Over 3,843 primary and secondary students are enrolled in schools in Alice Springs, with 2,187 students attending primary education, and 1,656 students attending secondary education. There are over 1,932 students enrolled in government schools and 1,055 students enrolled in independent schools.
<a href="Alice%20Springs%20School%20of%20the%20Air">Alice Springs School of the Air</a> delivers education to students in remote areas.
Tertiary and vocational.
The Alice Springs Campus of <a href="Charles%20Darwin%20University">Charles Darwin University</a> offers courses in <a href="TAFE">TAFE</a> and higher education. The Centre for Appropriate Technology was established in 1980 and provides a range of services to encourage and help Aboriginal people enhance their quality of life in remote communities.
Recreation and culture.
Events and festivals.
The town's focal point, the <a href="Todd%20Mall">Todd Mall</a>, hosts a number of Aboriginal art galleries and community events. Alice Springs' desert lifestyle has inspired several unique events, such as the Alice Desert Festival, the Red Centre NATS, Blacken Open Air music festival, <a href="Parrtjima">Parrtjima</a>, the <a href="Camel%20Cup">Camel Cup</a>, the <a href="Henley-on-Todd%20Regatta">Henley-on-Todd Regatta</a>, the <a href="Beanie%20Festival">Beanie Festival</a> and the <a href="Finke%20Desert%20Race">Finke Desert Race</a>. The Finke Desert Race is a 'there and back' challenge from Alice Springs to Aputula (Finke) Community, covering a 460-kilometre round trip.
Arts and entertainment.
Galleries and museums.
Alice Springs is known as the Aboriginal Art capital of Central Australia, home to many local and Aboriginal art galleries. <a href="Indigenous%20Australian%20art">Indigenous Australian art</a> is the more dominant, and galleries showcase the rich culture and native traditions that abound in Central Australia. Trade in Aboriginal art soared after the painting movement began at <a href="Papunya">Papunya</a>, a Central Australian Aboriginal settlement, and swept other indigenous communities. Central Australia is the home of some of the most prominent names in Aboriginal art, including <a href="Emily%20Kngwarreye">Emily Kngwarreye</a>, <a href="Minnie%20Pwerle">Minnie Pwerle</a>, <a href="Clifford%20Possum%20Tjapaltjarri">Clifford Possum Tjapaltjarri</a>, <a href="Albert%20Namatjira">Albert Namatjira</a> and <a href="Wenten%20Rubuntja">Wenten Rubuntja</a>.
The Museum of Central Australia / Stehlow Research Centre features some of the most important natural history and archival materials tied to the history and culture of the region. The Strehlow Archives also contain materials linked to the Arrernte people of Central Australia. The <a href="Araluen%20Centre%20for%20Arts%20and%20Entertainment">Araluen Centre for Arts and Entertainment</a> presents world-class ballets and orchestras, as well as local performances. The Women's Museum of Australia (formerly <a href="National%20Pioneer%20Women%27s%20Hall%20of%20Fame">National Pioneer Women's Hall of Fame</a>) is located in the grounds of Old Alice Springs Gaol in the Heritage Precinct. Here women's stories from across Australia are presented with the lives of outback women as well as stories from the Old Gaol and Labour Prison. Objects include a large "Signature" quilt with signatures of over 300 women first in their field and a 4.2 m long Aviatrix tapestry celebrating the high flying lives of Australia's aviatrixes.
The town has some excellent small museums. The extensive collection at the Old Timer's Traeger Museum on the North Stuart Highway includes artefacts from the town's early Afghan and German residents, traditional Aboriginal artefacts and objects which show the early fusion of European and Aboriginal cultures, such as a <a href="Spinifex%20%28plant%29">spinifex</a>-handled glass-bladed knife. Included in the collection are <a href="soapstone">soapstone</a> carvings by <a href="Arrernte%20people">Arrernte</a> artist <a href="Erlikilyika">Erlikilyika</a>.
Library, archives and other collections.
Alice Springs is home to the <a href="Alice%20Springs%20Public%20Library">Alice Springs Public Library</a>, also known as the Nevil Shute Memorial Library. The library, in addition to its general borrowable collections (including e-resources), is also home to two special, not-for-loan, collections. These are the Alice Springs Collection and the Akaltye Atheme Collection, both of which specifically collect Central Australian content, including Aboriginal language resources (from around 16 local languages) and cultural heritage information. The Alice Springs Collection also holds a significant digital collection, including PDF copies of the "<a href="Centralian%20Advocate">Centralian Advocate</a>" from 1947  to  2015, and over 6000 images, primarily from the Central Australian Historical Images Collection.
Library & Archives NT also has offices in Alice Springs, located at Minerals House on Hartley Street, which holds archival collections relating to Central Australia, including Tennant Creek. Collections held here include community collections and government archives.

Outdoors.
Leisure and entertainment activities include hiking in the nearby <a href="MacDonnell%20Ranges">MacDonnell Ranges</a> and driving the four-wheel-drive tracks at <a href="Finke%20Gorge%20National%20Park">Finke Gorge National Park</a>.
Parks and gardens.
The <a href="Alice%20Springs%20Desert%20Park">Alice Springs Desert Park</a> was created to educate visitors about the many facets of the surrounding desert environment. The arid climate botanic garden, <a href="Olive%20Pink%20Botanic%20Garden">Olive Pink Botanic Garden</a>, is a short distance from the town centre. They were named after anthropologist, naturalist and artist <a href="Olive%20Pink">Olive Pink</a>, who lived in the town for almost 30 years and died in 1975. She was well known locally and referred to by all as Miss Pink. The <a href="Alice%20Springs%20Reptile%20Centre">Alice Springs Reptile Centre</a> is located in the town centre.
Sport.
Alice Springs has a high rate of participation in many different sports, including tennis, <a href="field%20hockey">hockey</a>, <a href="Australian%20rules%20football">Australian rules football</a>, basketball, baseball, golf, soccer, <a href="cricket">cricket</a>, <a href="rugby%20football">rugby</a> and boxing.
Australian rules football is a particularly popular sport in Alice Springs in terms of both participation and as a <a href="spectator%20sport">spectator sport</a>. The <a href="Central%20Australian%20Football%20League">Central Australian Football League</a> formed in 1947 has several teams. The sport is particularly popular in Indigenous communities. The local stadium, <a href="Traeger%20Park">Traeger Park</a>, has a 10,000 seat capacity and was designed to host (pre-season) <a href="Australian%20Football%20League">AFL</a> and was the home to the <a href="Northern%20Territory%20Thunder">Northern Territory Thunder</a> until 2019. In 2004, an AFL pre-season Regional Challenge match between <a href="Collingwood%20Football%20Club">Collingwood Football Club</a> and <a href="Port%20Adelaide%20Football%20Club">Port Adelaide Football Club</a> attracted a capacity sell-out crowd.
Both codes of Rugby are played in Alice Springs. <a href="Rugby%20Union">Rugby Union</a>, managed by the Central Australian Rugby Union Association (CARU) is played in conjunction with the Northern Territory Rugby Union calendar which runs during Darwins dry season. The Central Australian Rugby Union administers a four team competition based in Alice Springs with matches played between October and March at <a href="ANZAC%20Oval">ANZAC Oval</a>. The First Central Australian Club Competition commenced in 1986. There are four senior teams; Dingo Cubs Rugby Union, Kiwi Warriors Rugby Union, Eagles Rugby Union and Devils Rugby Union. 
<a href="Rugby%20league">Rugby league</a> has been a part of the local sporting scene since 1963. The Australian Rugby League has held a number of pre-season games in Alice Springs, at <a href="ANZAC%20Oval">ANZAC Oval</a>. The local competition is the <a href="Central%20Australian%20Rugby%20Football%20League">Central Australian Rugby Football League</a>, and sanctions both Junior and Senior Rugby League matches. The season usually kicks off around March/April and runs through to Late August. There are four senior teams in Alice Springs: Wests, Memo, United and Vikings. Matches are held during the winter months at ANZAC oval on Saturday afternoons.
Organized baseball has been played in Alice Springs since the mid-1950s. Currently under the national organisation of the <a href="Australian%20Baseball%20Federation">Australian Baseball Federation</a>, the Alice Springs Baseball Association organises baseball competitions for youth players aged 5 to 18 and an adult competition played at Jim McConville Park and on Lyel Kempster Field at Traeger Park. As part of the worldwide <a href="Little%20League">Little League</a> network, Alice Springs players and compete in the Australian National Little League competitions.
The <a href="Alice%20Springs%20Golf%20Course">Alice Springs Golf Course</a>, an 18-hole championship layout golf course designed by the architects Thomson Wolveridge, was opened in 1985 by a challenge match between top professionals Greg Norman and Johnny Miller. The course record of 64 is held jointly by, amateur members, Leigh Shacklady and Kerryn Heaver, beating professional Stuart Appleby's 65. Adam Scott won the Australian Boys Amateur Championship held there in 1997.
Cricket is a popular sport in Alice Springs and is primarily played at Traeger Park. The <a href="Imparja%20Cup">Imparja Cup</a> Cricket Carnival first was played in 1994 and attracts Indigenous teams from all across Australia. The four main clubs are Federal Demons CC, Rovers CC, RSL Works CC and Wests CC.
Soccer is popular among the younger community. A high number of children play it. Soccer is also played frequently by amateur adults in different divisions. There is also an all-African league for soccer in Alice Springs. The most successful Club in the town is <a href="Alice%20Springs%20Celtic%20FC">Alice Springs Celtic</a>.
The Traeger Park sporting complex also hosts tennis, baseball, boxing, swimming, <a href="canoe%20polo">canoe polo</a>, hockey, basketball, squash, badminton, gymnastics and skateboarding.
A unique sporting event, held annually, is the <a href="Henley-on-Todd%20Regatta">Henley-on-Todd Regatta</a>, also known as the <a href="Todd%20River">Todd River</a> Race. It is a sand river race with bottomless boats and it remains the only dry river <a href="regatta">regatta</a> in the world. Another unusual sporting event is the <a href="Camel%20Cup">Camel Cup</a>. The annual <a href="Camel%20Cup">Camel Cup</a> is held in July at Blatherskite Park, part of the Central Australian Show Society grounds. It is a full day event featuring a series of races using <a href="camel">camel</a>s instead of horses.
Every year, on the Queen's Birthday long weekend, the annual <a href="Finke%20Desert%20Race">Finke Desert Race</a> is held. It is a gruelling off-road race that runs from Alice Springs to the Finke community, then back again the next day. The total length of the race is roughly . It attracts spectators, who camp along the whole length of the track, and roughly 500 competitors, buggies and bikes, every year, making it the biggest sporting event in the Alice Springs calendar.
Drag racing is held at the <a href="Alice%20Springs%20Inland%20Dragway">Alice Springs Inland Dragway</a> which in June 2013 hosted a round of the national Aeroflow Sportsman Drag Racing Championship. In September 2017 12 people were injured when burning fuel sprayed from a drag-racing car onto a crowd of spectators at the <a href="Red%20CentreNATS">Red CentreNATS</a> competition.
Alice Springs is also home to the <a href="Arunga%20Park%20Speedway">Arunga Park Speedway</a>, a 402-metre <a href="Oval%20track%20racing">dirt oval</a> speedway. The speedway runs from August to March and caters to cars, <a href="Motorcycle%20speedway">solos</a> and <a href="Sidecar%20speedway">sidecars</a>. Located just off the Stuart Highway on the northern edge of the town, Arunga Park hosted the <a href="Australian%20Sidecar%20Speedway%20Championship">Australian Sidecar Championship</a> in 1985 and the <a href="Australian%20Individual%20Speedway%20Championship">Australian Solo Championship</a> in <a href="1991%20Australian%20Individual%20Speedway%20Championship">1991</a>.
Crime.
Property crime and violent crime, including <a href="domestic%20violence">domestic violence</a>, often linked to <a href="alcohol%20and%20crime">alcohol abuse</a>, has been a significant social issue in Alice Springs in the 21st century, with most of the victims being residents of the town. Many approaches and programs have been tried over the years, with varying levels of success. there has been a downward trend in most categories of crime.
Media.
Alice Springs is served by both local and national radio and television services. The government-owned <a href="Australian%20Broadcasting%20Corporation">ABC</a> provides four broadcast radio stations – local radio <a href="783%20ABC%20Alice%20Springs">783 ABC Alice Springs</a> and the national networks <a href="Radio%20National">ABC Radio National</a>, <a href="ABC%20Classic%20FM">ABC Classic FM</a> and <a href="Triple%20J">Triple J</a>. The national Christian radio network <a href="Vision%20Radio%20Network">Vision Radio Network</a> broadcasts on 88.0 FM.
Commercial radio stations are <a href="8HA">8HA</a> 900 <a href="Hertz">kHz</a> and <a href="Sun%2096.9">Sun 96.9</a> <a href="Megahertz">MHz</a> and <a href="community%20radio">community radio</a> is provided by <a href="8CCC">8CCC</a> <a href="102.1FM">102.1FM</a> and <a href="Indigenous%20Australians">indigenous</a> broadcaster <a href="CAAMA%20Radio">CAAMA Radio</a> 100.5 MHz.
Alice Springs is home to Australia's largest Indigenous media company. The Central Australian Aboriginal Media Association (CAAMA) consists of a radio station (CAAMA Radio), music recording label (CAAMA Music), television and film production company (CAAMA Productions) and CAAMA technical. CAAMA serves to record and promote indigenous talent across its own radio network (one of the largest transmission footprints in the world), and through sales of CD's and screening of CAAMA movies and documentaries on national broadcasters.
Five broadcast television services operate in Alice Springs – commercial stations <a href="Imparja%20Television">Imparja Television</a> (<a href="callsign">callsign</a> IMP-9), <a href="Southern%20Cross%20Central">Southern Cross Central</a> (QQQ31) and <a href="Central%20Digital%20Television">Ten Central (CDT)</a> (CDT-5), and the Government-owned <a href="ABC%20Television%20%28Australia%29">ABC</a> (ABAD7) and <a href="Special%20Broadcasting%20Service">SBS</a> (SBS28). Imparja has a commercial agreement with the <a href="Nine%20Network">Nine network</a>. Southern Cross Central and Ten Central have programming affiliations with both the <a href="Seven%20Network">Seven Network</a> and <a href="Network%20Ten%20Australia">Network Ten Australia</a>.
Digital television transmissions have commenced in Alice Springs. New channels provided by the ABC and SBS can be received with a digital set top box or digital television. Additional channels from the commercial broadcasters that are available in most other areas of Australia are expected to commence transmission in 2011–2012. Analogue television transmissions in Alice Springs switched off on 31 December 2013.
<a href="Imparja%20Television">Imparja Television</a> is operated from studios in Alice Springs. It has a program affiliation contract with the <a href="Nine%20Network">Nine Network</a>. The programming schedule on Imparja is the same as Nine Darwin <a href="NTD-8">NTD-8</a> and Channel 9 Brisbane, with variations in Imparja's schedule for local <a href="Australian%20rules%20football">Australian rules football</a>, <a href="rugby%20league">rugby league</a>, the children's show "Yamba's Playtime", news, regional weather, and other programs produced in Alice Springs by the station. Infomercials are shown in place of Home Shopping and other programs overnight and in some daytime timeslots. <a href="National%20Indigenous%20Television">NITV</a> is broadcast on the second channel allocated to Imparja by the Federal Government.
The "<a href="Centralian%20Advocate">Centralian Advocate</a>" newspaper was founded on 24 May 1947 and was published on Tuesdays and Fridays. However, since 2020, it has stopped printing.
Infrastructure.
Transport.
Located on the <a href="Adelaide-Darwin%20railway">Adelaide-Darwin railway</a>, Alice Springs is accessible by train. <a href="Alice%20Springs%20railway%20station">Alice Springs railway station</a> is visited by "<a href="The%20Ghan">The Ghan</a>", operated by <a href="Journey%20Beyond">Journey Beyond</a>, on its journey between Adelaide and <a href="Darwin%2C%20Northern%20Territory">Darwin</a>. The train arrives twice weekly in each direction.
The line first opened to Alice Springs in 1929, as the <a href="Narrow%20gauge%20railways%20in%20Australia">narrow gauge</a> <a href="Central%20Australia%20Railway">Central Australia Railway</a>. It was not until 1980 that the current <a href="standard%20gauge">standard gauge</a> line was opened, which was extended to Darwin in 2004.
There are daily express coach services to and from Adelaide and Darwin servicing Alice Springs. The <a href="Stuart%20Highway">Stuart Highway</a>, running north from Adelaide to Darwin via Alice Springs, is Northern Territory's most important road. The distance from Alice Springs to Adelaide is and to Darwin is .
There are daily flights from <a href="Alice%20Springs%20Airport">Alice Springs Airport</a> to <a href="Adelaide">Adelaide</a>, <a href="Ayers%20Rock">Ayers Rock</a> (Uluru), <a href="Cairns">Cairns</a>, <a href="Darwin%2C%20Northern%20Territory">Darwin</a>, Melbourne, <a href="Perth%2C%20Western%20Australia">Perth</a> and Sydney. There are also nonstop flights a few times a week to <a href="Brisbane">Brisbane</a>. Two airlines serve Alice Springs: <a href="Qantas">Qantas</a> and <a href="Virgin%20Australia">Virgin Australia</a>.
Alice Springs is a base for the <a href="Royal%20Flying%20Doctor%20Service%20of%20Australia">Royal Flying Doctor Service of Australia</a>.
